12/12 Should do what they can to make sure they're being taken care of in the ways we promised we would take care of them after the war.
11/11 Then I will. And anyone else who relied on their interpreters, as we all did...
10. So I emailed him today because if I can help him just a fraction of the amount he helped us in Fallujah...

9. Mike was indefatigable. He worked exceptionally hard.
And he believed in the U.S. The concept of the U.S.
8. Because it's unclear what will happen to him now, even if he has a green card.
7. The last time I heard from the best interpreter I had in the Marine Corps was in 2014...but I sent him an email today.
6. He emaild me to say he was granted asylum in 2013 and got his green card in 2014.
5. I sent Mike a note, but didn't hear back. Then tried him again a few years later.
4. I said that having an interpreter like Mike was like having an extra Corporal in my platoon.
3. I still have the letter I sent in support of his application for asylum...
2. "Mike" was applying for asylum and needed whatever help I could give.
1. A law firm emailed me in 2010 to ask me if I'd write a letter of recommendation for one of their clients: my interpreter from Fallujah
